This implies that the western continuation of the older (pre-25 Ma) Argentera-Cuneo Line, delimiting the southern boundary of the indenting Ivrea mantle wedge and overlying internal Western nappe stack during the stage 2 top-WNW thrusting in the arc of the Western Alps, must be cut off by a N-S striking sinistral shear zone (Figs. 1, 6). This putative shear zone, which is only schematically drawn in Fig. 6, delimits the western edge of the Ligurian Alps affected by these 50 km of Apenninic top N thrusting from a narrow strip of the Southern Alps retro-belt in the west.

Eastward, i.e. north of Genova, the northern limit of the metamorphic core of the Ligurian Alps bends into a N-S strike and is exposed at the surface forming the well-known Sestri-Voltaggio line (or zone; Cortesogno and Haccard 1984) that is often taken as representing the Alps–Apennines junction (e.g. Castellarin 2001). Although reworked in later Neogene times (Crispini et al. 2009) this line basically represented a Late Paleocene to Early Eocene normal fault (Hoogerduijn Strating 1994) sealed by the deposits of the Tertiary Piedmont Basin. This normal fault juxtaposes the high-pressure rocks of the Voltri Group in the west (1.5–2.5 GPa), attributed to the Alpine lower plate, with low metamorphic grade units to the east (Sestri-Voltaggio Zone, various Ligurian flysch units and finally the Antola nappe; see Figure 8d in Molli et al. 2010), whose grade of metamorphism progressively decreases eastward and up-section (see Figure 2 in Capponi et al. 2009). It finally reaches the diagenetic zone in terms of illite crystallinity (Ellero et al. 2001) over a short horizontal distance of only some 5–7 km. Following Elter and Pertusati (1973) who considered the Antola nappe as an integral part of the former Alps that became backthrusted during Alpine orogeny, we attribute the units east of the Sestri-Voltaggio normal fault to the Alpine upper plate (Fig. 6).

The unknown Alpine-type basement of the Torino hills buried under the deposits of the Tertiary Piedmont Basin and the Antola nappe were mapped together as parts of a strip of former Alpine upper plate units mostly buried under Cenozoic deposits in Fig. 6. During the Apenninic orogeny, together with the metamorphic core of the Ligurian Alps, they thrusted the External Liguride units of the Monferrato hills along the Rio Freddo Fault Zone (Piana 2000) striking NW-SE between the Torino and Monferrato hills. The Rio Freddo Fault Zone links up with the E-W-striking Villalvernia-Varzi line (Fig. 1), a Late Oligocene to Early Miocene thrust, active during the deposition of a part of the Tertiary Piedmont basin fill, with a strong sinistral strike slip component (Laubscher et al. 1992; Schumacher and Laubscher 1996). This sinistral transpressional fault is responsible for laterally transporting the External Ligurides exposed in the Monferrato hills in front of the Antola nappe and the Torino hills Alpine basement. At its eastern termination the Villalvernia-Varzi line bends into a N-S-strike as it transforms into an Apenninic top NNE thrust of the Antola nappe over the external Ligurides in the north and over the Internal Ligurides further south (Fig. 6). The polyphase history of the Antola nappe, with early and Alpine top-NW thrusting and folding, followed by top-NNE Apenninic thrusting over the Ligurides, is well documented (e.g. Marroni et al. 1999, 2002a; Levi et al. 2006). Offshore the continuation of this thrust is only tentatively drawn in Fig. 6; southward it is interpreted to eventually abut the northern continuation of the west-dipping upper/lower plate boundary of the Apennines orogen.

The next eastward unit of the Apennines, the Internal Ligurides, have also to be considered as having represented an integral part of the former Alps. They occupied an upper plate position before they became backthrusted to the NNE during the Apenninic orogeny. The internal Ligurides are characterized by the presence of classical ophiolites and an Upper Jurassic to Lower Cretaceous sedimentary cover (cherts, Calpionella limestone and Palombini shales) associated with Upper Cretaceous–Paleocene turbiditic sequences (Marroni and Pandolfi 1996) that represent the pelagic cover of the ophiolitic basement of the Piedmont-Liguria ocean (Decandia and Elter 1972) whose stratigraphy is virtually indistinguishable from that of the ophiolites of the Alps sensu stricto (Bernoulli et al. 2003). Moreover, since the pioneering work of Grandjacquet and Haccard (1977) several authors evidenced classical structural overprinting patterns at all scales, clearly showing that the early tectonic history of the Internal Ligurides was characterized by a top W to NW Alpine tectonic fingerprint, associated with low-grade metamorphism reaching some 300 °C (Pertusati and Horrenberger 1975; van Wamel 1987; Marroni and Pandolfi 1996; Ellero et al. 2001).

The External Ligurides are far-travelled and detached units that are confined to the northernmost Apennines between Torino and Bologna (Fig. 6). They overlie thin slices of Subligurian units and the Cervarola unit representing flysch deposits of the Adriatic foredeep outcropping in two small windows (Molli et al. 2010). The External Ligurides dominantly consist of detached Cretaceous-Paleocene flysch sequences (Helminthoid flysch) overlying basal mélange-type complexes (Marroni et al. 1998, 2001, 2002b). Two main subgroups of units can be recognized: those associated with ophiolites and with ophiolite derived debris (Molli 1996), and others without ophiolites and associated with fragments of Mesozoic sedimentary sequences and conglomerates with continental Adria affinity often remarkably similar to those found in the Alpine upper plate units of the Préalpes Romandes (Elter et al. 1966). Hence, the External Ligurides are regarded as representing the former ocean-continent transition within the Adria plate. Very commonly the stratigraphic base of the Oligocene part of the Epiligurian basins only exhibits a modest angular unconformity up to few tens of degrees (Piazza et al. 2016). Due to the syn-depositional sinistral transpression during Oligocene to Early Miocene times sealed by a Burdigalian unconformity mentioned earlier, the base of the Burdigalian and younger deposits of the Epiligurian succession locally overlies overturned older sequences of Late Cretaceous to Early Miocene successions (Piazza et al. 2016). In summary, the External Ligurides represent an ocean-continent transition area within the Adria upper plate of the Alps that was only locally overprinted by substantial late Alpine deformations of Oligocene to Early Miocene age, largely synchronous with stage 2 deformation in the Western Alps.

A substantial Alpine overprint has not been documented in the southerly adjacent Tuscan Ligurides, representing a Piedmont-Liguria ophiolitic sequence identical to that observed in the Internal Ligurides or the Alps (Principi et al. 2004). Due to massive extension locally leading to core complex formation (Brunet et al. 2000), Tuscany exposes deep portions of the Apenninic orogen that locally reached blueschist facies conditions with pressures up to some 1.3 GPa (Rossetti et al. 2002), mostly affecting the underlying Tuscan nappe that represents the lower plate unit during Apenninic orogeny. Locally, also the immediately overlying Tuscan Ligurides (Jolivet et al. 1998; Brunet et al. 2000; Rossetti et al. 2002) became involved in subduction during the Apenninic orogeny. Hence, it is likely that the Tuscan Ligurides only became involved in W-directed Apenninic subduction and suffered penetrative deformation within a W-dipping subduction channel. A significant ophiolitic complex that is part of the Tuscan Ligurides is exposed on Gorgona Island (Orti et al. 2002). Metasediments associated with these ophiolites suffered blueschist facies metamorphism reaching about 1.5 GPa at around 25 Ma (Rossetti et al. 2001). Gorgona island is located far offshore Tuscany (Fig. 6) and very close to the northern continuation of the new plate boundary that formed during the earliest stages of Apenninic orogeny associated with W-directed subduction and subsequent roll back of the mantle slab below the North Apennines (Spakman and Wortel 2004). W-directed subduction initiated east of the Corsica basin that represents a >8.5 km thick rift basin filled with undeformed Late Oligocene to Burdigalian sediments (Mauffret et al. 1999; Finetti 2005) deposited as the Adriatic slab started to roll back, causing extension in the Corsica basin located in the Apenninic upper plate. The range of radiometric ages obtained for the high-pressure metamorphism in the Tuscan units is also significantly younger (26–20 Ma; Rossetti et al. 2002) when compared with the radiometric ages obtained in the ophiolitic units of Corsica where Cretaceous to latest Eocene ages (Vitale Brovarone and Herwartz 2012, and references therein) have been obtained. In summary, the Tuscan Ligurides are very likely to only have been affected by Apenninic orogeny, associated with W-directed subduction in latest Oligocene to Miocene times.

The Mesozoic Adriatic passive margin stratigraphy that accreted to the overriding European plate (Corsica) and the Ligurides during the Apenninic orogeny is exposed in the Tuscan nappe. The Chattian-Aquitanian Macigno turbidites (Di Giulio 1999) represent the youngest sediments involved. This 2.5–3 km thick turbiditic sequence is testimony of the deposition of siliciclastics derived from the Alps, particularly from the Lepontine dome (Garzanti and Malusa 2008). This dome shed an immense volume of metamorphic basement estimated at 17–20 × 103 km3 (Di Giulio 1999) as the Lepontine dome was uplifted by retro-thrusting and exhumed by erosion. This led to deposition of the Macigno pile of turbidites onto the still undeformed Adriatic foredeep during retro-folding and thrusting of the Alps north of the Periadriatic Line, predating most of the backthrusting of the Southern Alps in Lombardy (Schmid et al. 1996). Related exhumation, erosion and re-deposition onto the still undeformed Adriatic continental margin are largely synchronous with stage 2 top-WNW thrusting and WNW-directed indentation of the Ivrea mantle wedge (Stage 2, 35–25 Ma).

The more external Apennines thrust sheets involve flysch deposits of the foredeep only. The Cervarola thrust sheet is made up of Aquitanian to Early Langhian turbidites that still received detritus from the Alps. The more external Umbria-Marche thrust sheets involve the Marnoso Arenacea sequence of Serravallian to Tortonian age (Di Giulio 1999). The post-Messinian frontal imbricates are buried below younger deposits of the Po plain (Picotti and Pazzaglia 2008).
